related.description: State and local officials think they made a big impression Wednesday on NBA officials who must decide whether to move the Hornets from Charlotte to New Orleans.
related.linkText: New Orleans: Hornets' move a slam dunk
related.title: Mayor: 'We can look forward to becoming an NBA city'
related.headline: Mayor: 'We can look forward to becoming an NBA city'

article.headline: Davis comes through in clutch against Pacers
article.linkText: Hornets tighten up East race with fourth straight win
article.story:
CHARLOTTE, N.C. (AP) -- The Charlotte Hornets finally have some of their swagger back from last year. It couldn't have come at a better time.
Davis

Baron Davis hit a 3-pointer with 15 seconds to play Wednesday night as the Charlotte Hornets tightened up the Eastern Conference playoff race with a 94-88 victory over the Indiana Pacers, their season-high fourth straight win. "Man, we're feeling good right now," Davis said. "We want to win every ballgame, that's our goal. Will that happen? Probably not. But we're looking to make up as much ground as possible just to have that fear factor heading into the playoffs." The Hornets, who went to the Eastern Conference semifinals last season, moved into a tie with the Pacers for the seventh playoff spot in the East. Charlotte holds a 2-1 edge in the series, with the final meeting between the teams set for Sunday in Indiana. Both teams are a game behind Philadelphia for the sixth spot and are only 3 1/2 games out of fourth place. "We know we can move up even more," guard David Wesley said. "Before, we were probably a little anxious to get there. Right now, we are a little more patient and have a little bit of our swagger back and a lot of confidence." Davis finished with 25 points and 10 assists for the Hornets, who went undefeated on their homestand. Jamal Mashburn added 19, including a pair of free throws with two seconds to play that sealed the win. Elden Campbell added 18, Wesley scored 14 and P.J. Brown had 13 rebounds. Jermaine O'Neal led Indiana with 20 points and 16 rebounds. Austin Croshere scored 16, Jonathan Bender had 13, Reggie Miller 12 and Ron Artest 11. "They basically out-hustled us," Artest said. "It was a game they needed and they got it. Now we need to get it back." The Hornets were clinging to a 92-88 lead with 30 seconds to play when they called timeout to set up Davis' shot. He kept the ball the entire time, looking for his opportunity. It came when both defenders shifted over to Mashburn, leaving Davis a brief moment to set his feet. Kevin Ollie came late to try to stop the shot, but Davis let it fly over Ollie's arms and into the basket. "I was wide open, if I get that shot 10 times I'm going to take it 10 times," Davis said. "A wide-open 3 with the game on the line, you better believe I'm throwing it up." The Pacers said they should have known better then to leave Davis open. "Baron is a great player, he does what it takes to lead his team and knocks down big shots," Croshere said. "We were right there until he hit that shot." Charlotte led 74-68 at the start of the quarter but went cold as the Pacers pulled within three points twice, cutting it to 78-75 on Jamaal Tinsley's free throws with 6:12 to go. The Hornets then had a 9-3 run, getting five straight from Wesley, to open an 87-78 lead with 3:26 left. Wesley moved around a screen to score on a jumper, then called for the ball from the left side of the court as Davis pushed it up in transition. Davis looked at him, but momentarily ignored him as the defense moved away from Wesley. He then fired the ball over and Wesley tossed it up for the basket, pumping his fists in the air and bumping chests with Davis as Indiana called timeout. Perhaps the celebration irritated the Pacers, who rolled off a 10-2 run after the break to cut the score to 89-88 with 50 seconds left. O'Neal scored six straight points on three jumpers, and after a basket by Mashburn, Ollie scored on a jumper and a pair of free throws. The Hornets missed on their next possession, but got the rebound to reset the shot clock and set up Davis' shot. Game notes
NBA commissioner David Stern and a relocation committee toured New Orleans' arena Wednesday as part of the process to determine if the Hornets can leave Charlotte at the end of the season. ... Indiana's Brad Miller, who played with the Hornets during his rookie year, exchanged hugs with his former teammates before the opening tip, then was called with a technical foul for arguing a call during the first quarter. ... Bryce Drew and Indiana's Kevin Ollie both worked out for the Hornets last summer, with Charlotte signing Drew to a three-year deal. He didn't play, while Ollie gave the Pacers 17 minutes.

statistics.name: points
statistics.description: The number of points scored.

statistics.name: fieldGoals
statistics.description: Field Goal makes and attempts.

statistics.name: freeThrows
statistics.description: Free Throw makes and attempts.

statistics.name: assists
statistics.description: The number of times a player who passes the ball to a teammate in a way that leads to a score by field goal, meaning that he or she was "assisting" in the basket. There is some judgment involved in deciding whether a passer should be credited with an assist.

statistics.name: turnovers
statistics.description: The number of times a player loses possession to the other team.

statistics.name: minutes
statistics.description: The total number of minutes played.

statistics.name: assistTurnoverRatio
statistics.description: The average number of assists a player or team records per turnover

statistics.name: rebounds
statistics.description: The total number of rebounds (offensive and defensive).

statistics.name: defensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the defense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot by the offense.

statistics.description: The number of times when the offense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot.
